6.text:
Welcome back to my Dark Corner of This
World.

8.text: "It was regretable you ever left us."

10.text:
When alien invaders land on Earth what's
the first thing they do?

14.text: Blow stuff up? Kidnap women? Or...

17.text: "We'd like a loan from your bank."

21.text: This only happens in British films.

24.text: Only in England would alien invaders apply for a small business loan to fund their invasion.

37.text: This is 'They Came From Beyond Space'.

39.text:
which follows a scientist apparently
played by BBC Breakfast's Bill Turnball

44.text: "I also happen to be in love with you"

46.text: Who in between scoring with much younger women...

48.text: "I might even make you a cup of tea."

50.text:
Tries to solve the mystery of what aliens
are doing on a small farm.

55.text: And it really is a mystery.

57.text:
"When the right time comes you'll
understand."

61.text:
You say that, but for the vast majority of
this film

64.text: I had and no idea what was going on.

67.text: "I don't know, can't make it out."

77.text: "Control of vocal cords akward... but adequate."

92.text: aliens that can be trapped just by closing the rain hood of your car.

107.text: "Conquer and rule Earth, why would we want to do that?"

110.text:
And each time I hero achieves something,
breaking into the farm,

122.text:
Overcoming every alien he meets with
frankly baffeling ease.

133.text: I expect a little more the plot to be revealed.

136.text: "I've come to tell you why you're here."

140.text: but surely the rescued girlfriend will be able to tell us what's going on.

149.text: Now this withholding of information can work, in films like the 39 Steps for example

154.text: because it puts us into the same position as the hero desperate to know what's going on...

159.text: and not knowing what to do.

161.text: "We've got to keep them from taking off."

163.text:
Why? I have all the information
you have...

166.text: and I don't know why that's essential.

168.text: "I would like to know what's going on down here."

170.text:
Doctor Curtis keeps telling us he has
no idea what's going on,

173.text:
but he acts as if he knows exactly what's
going on.

176.text: "I don't belive in any of this."

178.text: He figures out the alien tech,

183.text: builds a helmet to prevent mind control,

188.text:
and no point does he demonstrate
even the slightest surprise that aliens have invaded Cornwall

197.text:
Now personally I think that about half
way through even the most patient viewer

201.text:
is going to decide that life is just too
damn short and give up.

205.text:
But if you do hang on to the end that is
a full explanation.

209.text: The aliens are stranded on the moon

211.text: "The ship crashed on this moon of your Earth."

215.text: Despite being able to pilot meteorites in formation to get to Earth.

219.text: "Good heveans, it looks like shooting stars, a whole flock of them."

222.text:
and they need to get into Doctor Curtis'
mind to be able to build their rocket home.

227.text: "There is knowledge there that we need, it's been too long withheld."

231.text: "what possible satisfaction of glory could we find...

234.text: "in ruling a race who's most intelligent life force...

But, those massive plot holes aside does
all add up

249.text: and it turns out it's all just a terrible misunderstanding

253.text:
and everything is sorted out with a firm
handshake.

Which is a very British way  of ending a
film,

263.text: it's just not a very satisfying wayof dealing with this slave meant if humanity
